ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I refined my interpretive, research, and writing skills. I learned a lot about key themes in Silk Road history, and about best practices when writing histories of the Silk Road.
This course developed my writing skills. It made me more knowledgeable on the subject matter.
I felt like I learned a lot of good history skills in this course (writing a historiographer essay, doing primary source research, etc)
Learning how to utilise archives for historical research, as well as planning a paper far in advance.

Knowledge about the Silk Road, both about the modern explorers along it and about its ancient history. But most importantly, the ability to write history papers. The course helped me to improve my writing skills more than any other class did.

Knowledge was twofold: first, learned about the fascinating history of the Silk Road, including the 20th century explorers who excavated it. Secondly, learned how to write a research paper using Yale's archival resources like at the Div school and Manuscripts and Archives.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is well-structured, and Professor Hansen puts a great emphasis on students developing their public speaking skills, which is why we sometimes engaged in debates. This was both a good way to develop speaking skills and internalize the material. We also spent multiple sessions in Yale's collections, libraries, and galleries, and these visits were always fascinating and insightful. There were times at which I which we would have delved more deeply into the historical content during class, but I understand that the primary purpose of this junior seminar was to teach us how to write an independent research paper. Professor Hansen, though she speaks her mind and can be rather demanding, means well and provides extremely detailed feedback designed to help you improve your writing.
Its small size was a big advantage. The Professor made the class very engaging for all.
The field trips to yales various collections were a huge strength. would have liked to spend more time on topics related to the Silk Road in west Asia / India

Strengths  Interactive aspects of class

Weakness  Weekly assignments make it hard to keep up with readings
It's superb, and everyone will gain a lot from the course. But Prof. Hansen is very demanding and a harsh grader, so be prepared.

Strengths: The course is well-organized and follows a clear trajectory. Field trips to different parts of Yale's research resources, such as Div school, Manuscripts and archives, and art gallery were also especially educational and entertaining.

Weaknesses: At times the big picture of the class was not as clear, as we dabbled around different time periods and topics.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to other students if they are looking to refine their writing skills and dabble in Silk Road history. Much of the second half of the course is dedicated to the research paper and is very self-driven, so be prepared for that. You can gain a lot if you put the appropriate time and effort in.
I would recommend this course to a student who wishes to develop their writing skills and learn more about the Silk Road.
Id recommend this course if you have an existing interest in the Silk Road / East Asian history.
Yes, if youd like to learn a lot under Prof Hansens expertise.
Yes! To me, this is the best class I've ever taken in college.

I would! I think this is a great history seminar to teach you how to write a research paper and/or senior thesis. The class is very structured and you'll have plenty of moments to refine your research paper. Additionally, the final research paper is not long at all, only 3,000 word count which from my experience is a bit lower than other seminars. Class was always engaging and fun to be in.
